facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1897 of 1967 was filed from the Judgment and Order dated 27th September 1966 of the Punjab High Court at Chandigarh in Civil Writ No. 1371 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1897 of 1967. From the Judgment and Order dated the 27th September, 1966, of the Punjab High Court at Cha

facts.text: The first appellant is the father of appellants 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by MATHEW, J. The first appellant is the father of appellants 2 and 3.

facts.text: The property in question belonged to the father of first appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant is the father of appellants 2 and 3. The property in question belonged to the father of first appellant.

facts.text: By a will executed by him, he bequeathed the property to appellants 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: The property in question belonged to the father of first appellant. By a will executed by him, he bequeathed the property to appellants 2 and 3.

facts.text: After the death of the testator, mutations in favour of appellants 2 and 3 were effected in the revenue records in the year 1996 B.K. 1939.

anchor.surface_text: By a will executed by him, he bequeathed the property to appellants 2 and 3. After the death of the tastator, mutations in favour of appellants 2 and 3 were effected in the revenue records in the year 1996 B.K.  1939 .

facts.text: The first appellant managed to get the mutation of the land in his name in 1944 for the reason that he wanted to get licence for a gun.

anchor.surface_text: 1939 . The first appellant managed to get the mutation of the land in his name in 1944 for the reason that he wanted to get licence for a gun.

facts.text: In 1955, when the Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act came into force, the first appellant was shown to be the owner of the land in the revenue records.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955, when the Pepsu Tanancy and Agricultural Lands Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act  came into force, the first appellant was shown to be the owner of the land in the revenue records.

facts.text: Chapter IV-A of the Act was inserted by Pepsu Act No. 15 of 1956 on October 30, 1956 and by s. 32A of this chapter, ceiling was placed on the holding of land.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter IV-A of the Act was inserted by Pepsu Act No. 15 of 1956 on October 30, 1956 and by s. 32A of this chapter, ceiling was placed on the holding of land.

facts.text: A suit was filed by appellants 2 and 3 for a declaration that the land belonged to them, that the mutation of the land in the name of the first appellant was for the purpose of enabling him to obtain a gun licence and that there was no transfer of the land to first appellant.

anchor.surface_text: A suit was filed by appellants 2 and 3 for a declaration that the land belonged to them, that, the mutation of the land in the name of the first appellant in the revenue records was for the purpose of enabling him to obtain a gun licence and that there was numbertransfer of the land to first appellant.

facts.text: The first appellant was the only defendant in the suit and he did not contest the suit and it was decreed on February 14, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant was the only defendant in the suit. He did number companytest the suit and it was decreed on February 14, 1961.

facts.text: A few weeks later, the Collector of Bhatinda declared no surplus land in the ownership and possession of the first appellant by order dated March 28, 1961, based on the civil court judgment and decree.

anchor.surface_text: A few weeks later, the question of- declaration of the surplus area of the  and in the hands of the, first appellant came up for companysideration before the Collector of Bhatinda. On the basis of the judgment and decree passed by the Civil Court that there was numbertransfer of the land to the first appellant, the Collector, by his order dated March 28, 1961, declared that there was numbersurplus land in the ownership and possession of the first appellant.

facts.text: The Act was amended by Act No. 16 of 1962 and s. 32-DD was introduced with retrospective effect from October 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was amended by Act No. 16 of 1962 and s. 32-DD was introduced into the Act with retrospective effect from October 30, 1956.

facts.text: The Collector made a reference under S. 15 of the Punjab Land Revenue Code to the Commissioner of Patiala for sanction to review his order dated March 28, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector thereupon made a reference presumably under S. 15 of the Punjab Land Revenue Code for sanction to the Commissioner of Patiala to review his order dated March 28, 1961, as it omitted to include the land in question in the holding of the first appellant on the basis of the judgment and decree.

facts.text: Sanction was given to the Collector, who reviewed the order and ignored the judgment and decree as per s. 32-DD and included the land in the holding of the first appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The sanction was given, the Collector reviewed the order and he refused to give effect to the judgment and decree by ignoring them as enjoined by s. 32-DD and included the land in the holding of the first appellant.

facts.text: The appellants filed a writ petition in the High Court of Punjab to quash the Collector's review order dated May 29, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a writ petition in the High Court of Punjab to quash this order. Before the High Court, three companytentions were raised by the appellants  1  that the Collector had numberjurisdiction to review his order dated March 28, 1961

facts.text: High Court overruled appellants' contentions and held the Collector's order dated May 29, 1963 valid under s. 32-DD.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court overruled all the companytentions and held that the order of the Collector was rendered null and void by virtue of the provisions of s. 32-DD and, therefore, the Collector had the power to determine by his order dated May 29, 1963, the surplus area after ignoring the judgment and decree.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the Collector had no jurisdiction to review his order dated March 28, 1961 under s. 15 of the Land Revenue Code.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did number rest its decision on s. 15 of the Punjab Land Revenue Code for holding that Collector had jurisdiction to pass the order dated May 20, 1963. facts.text: The Collector's order dated March 28, 1961 was valid when passed and became final as no one challenged it.

anchor.surface_text: That order of the Col- lector dated March 28, 1961 was a perfectly valid one when it was passed. No one challenged that order and it became final for all purposes.

facts.text: No notice was given to appellants 2 and 3 before the Collector passed the review order dated May 20, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: We are also number satisfied that the Collector was acting in companysonance with the principles of natural justice when he passed the order dated May 20, 1963, as he gave numberopportunity to appellants 2 and 3 of being heard.

facts.text: The civil court judgment declared that there was no real transfer of the land to the first appellant and the property remained in ownership of appellants 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: the effect of the declaration was that there was numberreal transfer of the property in favour of the first appellant and that the property remained always in the ownership of appellants 2 and 3, numberwithstanding the purported transfer evidenced by the mutation in the revenue records.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 32A Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Places ceiling on holding of land

anchor.surface_text: The Act was amended by Act No. 16 of 1962 and s. 32-DD was introduced into the Act with retrospective effect from October 30, 1956. That section reads 32-DD. Future tenancies in surplus area and certain judgments etc. to be ignored- Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, for the purposes of determining the sur- plus area of any person-  a  a tenancy created after the commencement of the Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands  Second Amendment  Act, 1956, in any area of land which could have been declared as the surplus area of such person and  b  any judgment, decree or order of a court or other authority, obtained after the commencement of that Act and having the effect of diminishing the area of such person which could have been declared as his surplus area shall be ignored.

concepts.interpretation: Requires ignoring judgments that have the effect of diminishing surplus area only if the land belonged to the person prior to judgment; declaration of no prior title does not diminish area.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: state of facts. Its declaratory, determinative and adjudicatory function is its distinctive characteristic. Its recording gives an official certificat

Foreign Compensation Commission the House of Lords has held that even if a tribunal had jurisdiction to enter upon an enquiry, the fact that it overlooked an applicable mandatory provision in the course of the enquiry Would denude it of its jurisdiction but we doubt whether that principle has any application in a case when the provision overlooked was not in actual existence at the time when the inquiry was conducted and the order was passed.

issues.text: Whether the civil judgment had the effect of diminishing the area of the first appellant which could have been declared as his surplus area under s. 32-DD(b)

anchor.surface_text: The land must have belonged to the first appellant prior to the judgment in order that it might be postulated that the judgment has the effect of diminishing the total area in his hands. To put it differently, prior to the judgment, the land must have belonged to him in order that it may be said that the effect of the judgment is to diminish the area of his holding.

holdings.text: The Collector had no jurisdiction to review his order dated March 28, 1961 under s. 15 of the Punjab Land Revenue Code.

anchor.surface_text: We are not satisfied that this is a correct approach to the question. The Collector purported to act under s. 15 of the Land Revenue Code, which, obviously, has noapplication.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.15 has no application to surplus area determinations; High Court did not rely on it anyway.

holdings.text: The Collector's order dated March 28, 1961 was perfectly valid when passed, unchallenged, and became final.

anchor.surface_text: That order of the Col- lector dated March 28, 1961 was a perfectly valid one when it was passed. No one challenged that order and it became final for all purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order considered civil judgment effect; no provision in retrospective amendment to reopen final orders.

holdings.text: Retrospective operation of s.32-DD does not render the prior valid final order of March 28, 1961 null and void.

anchor.surface_text: It was only when s. 32-DD was incorporated in the Act with retrospective effect from October 30, 1956 that the question arose whether that order was valid. The Collector could not have anticipated the en- actment of the section with retrospective effect and passed the order conforming to its.provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reopening provision in amendment; cannot stretch fiction to nullify prior valid order ab initio.

holdings.text: Anisminic principle of jurisdictional error does not apply where overlooked provision enacted retrospectively after the order.

anchor.surface_text: We are aware that in Anisminic Ltd. v. Foreign Compensation Commission the House of Lords has held that even if a tribunal had jurisdiction to enter upon an enquiry, the fact that it overlooked an applicable mandatory provision in the course of the enquiry Would denude it of its jurisdiction but we doubt whether that principle has any application in a case when the provision overlooked was not in actual existence at the time when the inquiry was conducted and the order was passed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedent as provision not existent at inquiry time.

holdings.text: The Collector violated principles of natural justice in passing the review order dated May 20, 1963 without notice or hearing to appellants 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: We are also not satisfied that the Collector was acting in consonance with the principles of natural justice when he passed the order dated May 20, 1963, as he gave noopportunity to appellants 2 and 3 of being heard.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affected parties (appellants 2 and 3) not heard; first appellant's hearing irrelevant.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether failure to observe audi alteram partem per se vitiates an order or requires showing prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think it necessary, to decide in this case whether the failure to observe the rule audi alteram partem would per se vitiate an order or whether it is also necessary to show prejudice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prejudice clear here as parties could have explained civil judgment nature.

holdings.text: The civil court judgment did not have the effect of diminishing the first appellant's surplus area under s.32-DD(b) as the land never belonged to him prior to the judgment.

anchor.surface_text: the effect of the declaration was that there was no real transfer of the property in favour of the first appellant and that the property remained always in the ownership of appellants 2 and 3, notwithstanding the purported transfer evidenced by the mutation in the revenue records.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.32-DD(b) ignores judgments diminishing area only if land belonged to person prior; here declared no prior title/transfer.

holdings.text: s.32-DD(b) language cannot be given unconfined operation; land must have belonged prior for judgment to have diminishing effect.

anchor.surface_text: It is impermissible to give the wide language employed in clause b of s. 32-DD an unconfined operation. ... The land must have belonged to the first appellant prior to the judgment in order that it might be postulated that the judgment has the effect of diminishing the total area in his hands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction to avoid absurdity; distinguishes fraudulent transfer declarations.

anchor.surface_text: We think the High Court went wrong in assuming that the Collector was right when he ignored the judgment by, his order dated May 20, 1963 on the ground that it had the effect of diminishing the area of the first appellant which companyld have been declared as his surplus.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment set aside as incorrect; Collector's review order dated May 20, 1963 held invalid due to lack of jurisdiction under s.15 Land Revenue Code, violation of natural justice (no notice to appellants 2 and 3), and misinterpretation of s.32-DD(b) as the civil judgment did not diminish the first appellant's holding but declared no real transfer ever occurred
